Introduction

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are rare but severe mucocutaneous reactions characterized by widespread epidermal necrolysis and sloughing.  By convention, SJS denotes <10% involvement of body surface area (BSA), >30% is designated as TEN, and 10%-30% is SJS/TEN overlap.  These conditions are considered dermatologic emergencies because they result in high morbidity and mortality rates (~25%).

Etiology and risk factors



SJS/TEN is caused by the following:



  • Medications (~80% of cases):  A wide range of medications have been implicated; these include antibiotics (eg, sulfa drugs, penicillins, cephalosporins), antiepileptic drugs (eg, phenytoin, carbamazepine), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and allopurinol.  Symptoms typically occur within a month of starting the offending medication.
  • Infections:  Mycoplasma pneumoniae and herpes simplex virus (HSV) are commonly implicated infections.
  • Idiopathic/other causes:  Some cases (~15%) have no identifiable cause or have a controversial cause (eg, chemical exposure, vaccinations).


Risk factors for the conditions include advanced age, malignancy, connective tissue disorders, and HIV.

Pathophysiology



Patients with a genetic predisposition for SJS/TEN are presented with a trigger (typically a drug antigen) that activates cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells to release cytotoxic proteins (eg, granulysin), which causes extensive keratinocyte apoptosis and subsequent epidermal necrosis.



Histopathologic examination typically shows full-thickness epidermal necrosis with detachment (

image 1
).  In addition, there may be evidence of apoptotic keratinocytes, perivascular lymphocytic infiltration, and dermal-epidermal separation.

Clinical presentation



SJS/TEN typically begin with prodromal symptoms followed by the development of cutaneous lesions.  Mucosal involvement is present in most cases (>90%).



  • Prodromal symptoms:  Nonspecific symptoms such as fever, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms are typically the first signs of SJS/TEN.
  • Cutaneous involvement:  Typically 3-4 days after the prodrome, tender erythematous macules or atypical target lesions develop on the face and thorax, which may rapidly spread to involve the limbs and mucous membranes.  Lesions coalesce and form bullae and vesicles.  The affected skin may exhibit a positive Nikolsky sign, in which slight rubbing or pressure causes the separation of layers of epidermis, exposing underlying erythematous skin.
  • Mucosal involvement:  Oral involvement (eg, erosions cheilitis) is most common.  Ocular involvement can lead to conjunctivitis, eyelid edema, corneal erosions, and potentially sight-threatening complications such as corneal ulceration and perforation.  Genital mucosa can also be affected.


Additional extracutaneous complications can also occur in almost every organ system.  Acute kidney injury is common in 20%-30% of patients.  Many patients develop pulmonary complications, including direct lung injury (eg, sloughing of bronchial epithelium), pneumonia, and respiratory failure.  Bacteremia/sepsis (30%-50% of patients) is a common cause of mortality.  Hematologic abnormalities such as leukopenia, anemia, and disseminated intravascular coagulation can occur.



The process typically occurs over 7-9 days before it ceases and reepithelialization begins.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of SJS/TEN relies primarily on clinical evaluation.  SJS/TEN should be considered in any patient with a sudden, painful cutaneous eruption, particularly when mucosal surfaces are involved.  Recent exposure to a causative medication or recent infection increases suspicion for the diagnosis.  Skin biopsy may be indicated to confirm the diagnosis and to exclude other similar conditions.

Differential diagnosis



  • Erythema multiforme (EM) (

    ):  an acute cell-mediated immune process most frequently associated with infections (especially HSV and mycoplasma).  Classic target lesions (
    image 2
    ) are typically papular and begin on the face and acral skin and spread centrally.  In contrast, SJS/TEN is typically caused by medications, and lesions are atypical target lesions (flat without 3 rings) that start on the trunk and become widespread.  Nikolsky sign is not present in EM.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  a mucocutaneous autoimmune blistering disease typically occurring in patients age 40-60.  Lesions (
    image 3
    ) consist of painful, flaccid blisters that easily rupture, forming erosions with a positive Nikolsky sign.  Mucosal surfaces are almost always affected but, in contrast to SJS/TEN, the oral mucosa is the most common initial site of involvement and systemic symptoms are typically absent.  Skin biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis and typically shows intraepithelial cleavage (
    image 4
    ) with detached keratinocytes (acantholysis).
  • Bullous pemphigoid (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  an autoimmune blistering disease that most commonly affects individuals age >60.  The prodromal phase consists of a pruritic, eczematous, or urticarial rash that may precede the development of bullae (
    image 5
    ) by weeks to months.  Mucosal involvement is rare, and pruritus, not tenderness as seen in SJS/TEN, is a prevailing symptom.  Subepidermal cleavage (
    image 6
    ) and linear deposition of IgG and/or C3 along the basement membrane are found on biopsy.
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ):  an infection, most common in infants and young children, caused by strains of exotoxin-producing Staphylococcus aureus that produce a diffusely erythematous, painful rash (
    image 7
    ) often preceded or accompanied by systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise).  Nikolsky sign is present.  Mucous membranes are spared in SSSS and the rash occurs most prominently in the skinfolds.
  • Urticaria:  a common, transient hypersensitivity disorder characterized by intensely pruritic, raised, erythematous plaques (wheals) (
    image 8
    ) that arise suddenly and resolve over several hours.  Biopsy (
    image 9
    ) is rarely required for diagnosis but, if obtained, typically shows a mixed inflammatory infiltrate (mononuclear cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils) surrounding superficial dermal venules.
  • Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS):  a severe cutaneous adverse reaction characterized by fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, and visceral organ involvement, typically occurring weeks (to months) after initiating a culprit medication (eg, anticonvulsants, allopurinol, sulfonamides, antibiotics).  Compared to SJS/TEN, distinguishing features include timing after drug exposure (weeks vs days with SJS/TEN), polymorphic rash (
    image 10
    ) with prominent eosinophilia, more extensive internal organ involvement (eg, lymphadenopathy, hepatitis), and rare/no mucocutaneous involvement or epidermal detachment (Nikolsky sign).
  • Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP): a rare severe cutaneous adverse reaction characterized by the sudden onset of numerous, nonfollicular sterile pustules on an erythematous background (
    image 11
    ), typically sparing the mucous membranes.  AGEP tends to have milder systemic involvement compared to SJS/TEN, with distinctive biopsy findings.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging



Laboratory evaluation and imaging are generally not helpful in diagnosing SJS/TEN.  However, laboratory testing (eg, viral serologies) can be helpful in identifying triggers (eg, HSV, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and assessing extracutaneous organ involvement (eg, liver function, renal function).  Imaging studies (eg, chest radiography, abdominal ultrasonography) may be indicated when there is evidence of organ dysfunction.

Management



Management of SJS/TEN involves primarily supportive care in a specialized setting, with the following guiding principles:



  • Discontinuation of causative agents:  Prompt discontinuation of all potentially implicated medications may improve the prognosis and reduce the severity of the disease.  Patients should avoid the causative medication in the future.
  • Assessment for admission to a specialized unit:  Two scoring systems (SCORTEN and ABCD-10), along with the percentage of total BSA affected, can help determine disease severity.  Patients with >10% of BSA involved and/or those with greater disease severity should be transferred to specialized centers (eg, dermatology units, burn centers).
  • Pain management, fluid resuscitation (similar to that for burn patients), and nutritional support are critical to improving the prognosis.
  • Wound care: Gentle wound care is required.  Mechanical trauma and friction should be avoided to minimize further skin detachment.
  • Infection prevention: Bacteremia is common and sepsis is a leading cause of death.  Prophylactic systemic antibiotics are not routinely recommended, but close surveillance for infection (eg, wound culture, blood cultures) and prompt treatment of identified infections are recommended.
  • Systemic medications: Systemic corticosteroids are often prescribed in the first few days of the disease, but there is no evidence that they are beneficial.  Other adjunct therapies have been studied (eg, tumor necrosis factor-alpha inhibitors, N-acetylcysteine, intravenous immunoglobulins), but their efficacy remains debatable.

Prognosis



SJS/TEN carries significant risk for morbidity and mortality, with reported mortality rates ranging from 5%-30%.  Prognosis is influenced by various factors, including age, extent of epidermal detachment, presence of comorbidities, and promptness of medical intervention.  Survivors may experience long-term sequelae, including ocular complications, chronic pain, mucosal scarring, and psychologic distress.

Summary



Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (

) represents an inflammatory reaction to drugs or certain infections that is characterized by a prodromal period (eg, fever, malaise) followed by development of coalescing erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation, typically with involvement of multiple mucosal surfaces.  The condition is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates, but the prognosis can be improved with rapid identification and discontinuation of offending medications and excellent supportive care at a specialized center.
